Myxofibrosarcoma is a rare malignant soft tissue tumor, most commonly affecting the extremities of elderly individuals. Paratesticular involvement is extremely uncommon and often presents a diagnostic challenge. We present the case of a male patient who presented with a painless, progressively enlarging right-sided scrotal swelling of 4 years’ duration. Clinical examination revealed a large scrotal mass with a non-palpable right testicle. Imaging and histopathological evaluation confirmed the diagnosis of paratesticular myxofibrosarcoma. We will mainly discuss the clinical presentation, imaging findings, and pathological features of this rare tumor. He also reported a decreased frequency of sexual activity due to the mass. The patient had no relevant past medical or surgical comorbidity. On clinical examination, the patient had stable vital signs with an Eastern Cooperative Oncology Group performance status of 0. A large, non-tender scrotal mass of soft to firm consistency was noted. The right testis was not palpable, while the left scrotal was normally positioned and palpable. There was no inguinal lymphadenopathy or overlying skin change ( Fig. 1 Fig. 1 Pre-operative pictures of the scrotal lesion in supine (A) and standing (B) positions. Fig. 1 Baseline laboratory investigations, including complete blood count, renal and liver function tests, and serum electrolytes, were within normal limits. Scrotal ultrasonography showed a large heterogeneous mass with no clear demarcation of the right testis, and the patient underwent further evaluation with pelvic magnetic resonance imaging (MRI). Axial pelvic MRI in T2 ( Fig. 2 Fig. 2 Fig. 2 Fig. 2 Fig. 3 Fig. 3 Fig. 2 Axial Pelvic MRI in T2 (A, B), T1 (C, D), T2 coronal (E), and T2 sagittal (F) sequences: They show a large (24cm × 20cm x 14cm- CCxAPxTR) heterogeneous infiltrative right hemi-scrotal mass (blue arrowheads in A-D). The lesion shows predominantly hyperintense signal on T2 and hypointense signal on T1. The right and left testes (red arrowheads in A-D) are splayed peripherally but have a sharp border against the mass. The epididymis is not separately seen. The coronal (E) and sagittal (F) T2 images show the scrotal skin thickening to a better advantage. Fig. 2 Fig. 3 Axial T1 C+ pelvic MRI: The lesion shows significant enhancement especially in its more proximal part (A) compared to its distal part (B). Fig. 3 Afterwards, surgical excision was performed. Intraoperatively, the scrotal skin was edematous. A firm, fibrous, well-vascularized mass was identified filling the entire right hemi-scrotum without invasion of the testis or cord structures. The mass was dissected from the scrotal wall and removed with overlying skin. Redundant skin was also generously excised. The right spermatic cord was identified and followed up to the testis, and it was preserved ( Fig. 4 The patient was seen at the follow-up clinic 1 week and 3 months after the surgery, and he reported to be recovering well with no urinary or sexual dysfunction. Fig. 4 Post-operative pictures of the resected mass lesion are seen (A) and (B). The mass had areas of necrosis and hemorrhage with multinodular growth pattern on gross examination. Fig. 4 3 Histopathology Hematoxylin and Eosin Staining ( Fig. 5 Fig. 5 Hematoxylin and Eosin Stains in x10 (A, B) and x40 (C) powers: Hypocellular and hypercellular areas composed of spindle to stellate cells admixed with elongated, curvilinear blood vessels in a myxoid background consistent with MFS. Fig. 5 4 Discussion Due to the absence of characteristic radiological or biochemical markers, MFS remains challenging to diagnose preoperatively. 1 , 4 1 1 , 2 1 6 Regarding scrotal imaging, in general, ultrasonography is adequate and often can be used as a standalone imaging modality in the majority of the cases. 5 It also helps in better delineation of the origin of intrascrotal tumors (testicular or extratesticular) and the relationship of the tumor to adjacent structures. where the tumor has unusually large size 6 , 7 The MRI features of sarcomatous tumors are not specific and are shared by leiomyosarcoma, fibroma, and adenomatoid tumors. These lesions usually have a low-intensity signal on the T1 sequence and a high signal intensity on the T2 sequence. 5 , 7 5 , 7 There is limited literature addressing the roles of radiotherapy and chemotherapy in MFS, and neither modality has shown consistent efficacy in improving survival outcomes. 3 , 6 2 2 Given the rarity of MFS, especially in uncommon locations, robust survival data are lacking, and standardized therapeutic strategies for metastatic disease have not been established. 3 1 , 3 , 4 Informed patient consent Informed consent was obtained from the patient for anonymized patient information to be published in this article.
